abstract.shortdesc: The condition element describes a state that the troubleshooting topic is intended to remedy. This information helps the user decide whether a troubleshooting topic might contain an applicable remedy for a problem.

section.title: Usage information
section.p: This section should add to or clarify information that is in the title or short description of the troubleshooting topic. If the title and short description adequately describes the condition, this element might be omitted.

section.title: Specialization hierarchy
section.p: The condition element is specialized from section. It is defined in the troubleshooting module.

example.title: Example
example.p:
In the following code sample, the condition element contains information that elaborates on the information provided by the title and short description:Nit - hardware documentation differentiates between a system receiving power and it powering up. Just flicking the power switch will "turn it on", but it may not power up across all its internal components.
Kris Eberlein, 12 February 2023
Can you suggest wording that would handle your nit?
FYI, this was an example topic in the "DITA 1.3 Troubleshooting" whitepaper.
example.codeblock:
System will not turn on Everything looks right, but the system still does not start. Condition

The system is plugged in, the power switch is on, but the system does not start.
example.p: Alternately, the short description could be enhanced and the condition element eliminated:
example.codeblock: <troubleshooting id="system-will-not-turn-on"> <title>System will not turn on</title> <shortdesc>he system is plugged in, the power switch is on, but the system does not start.</shortdesc>Missing "T" at the beginning of shortdesc <troublebody> <troubleSolution> <!-- ... --> </troubleSolution> </troublebody> </troubleshooting>
example.draft-comment:
The next paragraph seems introductory to troubleshooting in general. Not particularly detailed or relevant to <condition>.
Kris Eberlein, 11 February 2023
I agree that the paragraph is applicable to the troubleshooting topic in general. However, I think it is germane here because the example presents two different ways of describing the condition:
Title and short description
Title, short description, and condition
In my experience, an implementation usually picks one of these two approaches.
example.p: How implementations choose what markup patterns they use might depend on their stylesheets and how they deliver troubleshooting information to readers.
